title: Dinner on the Couch Tonight? Try These Fresh Takes On TV Dinners
text:
There are occasions that call for eating dinner in front of the TV — maybe it was a long week, everyone’s tired, the game’s on, it’s movie night or the family is binge watching something on Netflix. You’re going to want a little nosh in front of the tube anyway, so why not turn it into dinner and add some nutritional value, rather than down bowls of popcorn and chips?

Here are a few ideas for meals that are easy to eat out of hand, curled up and cozy on the couch. Some of these can also be frozen in individual portions for healthier, more economical versions of traditional TV dinners anyone in the family can reheat when they need a quick meal.

Dinner Bowls

Meals in bowls are all the rage, and can consist of just about anything. Most are based on cooked grains or noodles, topped with steamed or roasted fish or sautéed meats and veggies, sliced avocado, nuts and seeds — really, anything goes. The idea is that all the ingredients are layered in a shallow bowl rather than segregated on a traditional dinner plate, mixing everything together and making them easier to eat with one hand.

You'll Also Love: 20-Minute Meals for Busy Weeknights

Fried Egg Hash

Put an egg on anything — reheated grains, leftovers — and it’s transformed into dinner. Even if you have nothing more than a potato and some veg, dice them up and cook in a drizzle of oil in a hot skillet until tender and caramelized, then transfer them to a bowl and fry an egg (or three) in the hot pan. Curl up with a fork and a bottle of ketchup.

Mac & Cheese

There are few foods as comforting as baked mac & cheese. Use your favourite recipe and add bits of leftover ham or sausage, sautéed mushrooms, or whatever you like that goes with pasta and cheese. Divide between individual baking dishes and bake until bubbly and golden, then wrap yourself in a blanket and tuck in.

Thin Crust Bar-Style Pizza

Rather than order delivery, make the quickest, crispiest pizzas out of flour tortillas. Let everyone choose their own toppings and spread them out on the coffee table to share, or let everyone have their own. With ultra-crisp crusts, you won’t need much more than a stack of napkins.

Slow Cooker 'Thai' Chicken Thighs

Make your own frozen TV dinners by cooking a large batch of skinless, bone-in chicken thighs in the slow cooker! Combine 8 thighs, 1 cup salsa, ½ cup peanut butter, a couple tablespoons of lime juice and a shake of curry powder (and if you have a few more minutes, some fresh ginger and garlic, and perhaps a handful of chopped cilantro), cover and cook on low for 6 hours, or until the chicken is very tender and the sauce has thickened. Cook a pot of rice and divvy it between individual ovenproof dishes. Add some steamed broccoli, green beans or carrots, if you like. Cool, cover and freeze, then microwave when you need them. (Most slow cooker dishes freeze very well and can be done in individual portions.)

Noodle Bowls

A big pile of twirly, slurpy noodles makes a perfect TV pairing. Soak or cook up some Asian noodles, rice noodles or spaghetti and add broth, veggies, a squeeze of lime and squirt of sriracha. Or make a quick pad Thai sauce by whisking together 1/4 cup each ketchup, fish sauce and lime juice with 2 tablespoons of brown sugar. Add shredded leftover chicken, scrambled eggs, diced tofu, cooked shrimp, bean sprouts and fresh cilantro. Serve in a wide bowl with chopsticks.

You'll Also Love: 3 Salad Dressings that Might Actually Get Your Kids to Eat Salad

A Big Salad

Like Elaine on Seinfeld, you can do a big salad — like a regular salad, only bigger, with lots of stuff in it — to clean out the fridge and pantry. Start with a base of greens and then add grains, beans, veggies, cheese, hard boiled eggs, chopped apples, leftovers, toasted nuts and seeds — go for a variety of textures and something to add crunch, and take the bowl to the couch with your fork.
description: In a dinner rut? Try these seven dinner ideas designed for eating... in front of the TV!
